markdownRemark.excerpt: Tryhackme has been around for awhile now but actually took me some time to notice it. So during a pretty rainy and tedious afternoon around last September I…
markdownRemark.html:
Tryhackme has been around for awhile now but actually took me some time to notice it. So during a pretty rainy and tedious afternoon around last September I decided to give it a go. I setup my account and started looking for interesting boxes to play with.

Eventually I found something I liked and jump right in, but before doing it I decided documenting a pretty simple step-by-step of how I usually setup my environment before playing with the boxes.

Quick setup

Normally I start by getting the machine’s name and adding it to my /etc/hosts so I don’t have worry which IP address I’m currently dealing with. You can get this to work by doing:

$ sudo vim /etc/hosts

As a result, you might get something like this:

# The following lines are desirable for IPv4 capable hosts
127.0.0.1       localhost
10.10.129.210   tartarus.thm

# 127.0.1.1 is often used for the FQDN of the machine
127.0.1.1       mylocalhost  thishost

# The following lines are desirable for IPv6 capable hosts
::1             localhost ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
ff02::1         ip6-allnodes
ff02::2         ip6-allrouters

Noticed how I added the 10.10.129.210 followed by tartarus.thm. I usually add the thm indicating its a TryHackMe machine, but you can do whatever you want. This should get your local DNS set. You can test it by pinging the host directly:

$ ping -c 3  tartarus.thm

PING tartarus.thm (10.10.129.210): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 87.123.248.80: icmp_seq=0 ttl=60 time=18.299 ms
64 bytes from 87.123.248.80: icmp_seq=1 ttl=60 time=17.306 ms
64 bytes from 87.123.248.80: icmp_seq=2 ttl=60 time=11.631 ms

3 packets transmitted, 3 packets received, 0.0% packet loss

If the response you get looks like this, it means its working. Otherwise, make sure you have your VPN up and running as this might be the case.
